thread.title: Mets Web site declares team 'National League Champions' hours before Game 4
thread.title_full: Mets Web site declares team 'National League Champions' hours before Game 4

title: Mets Web site declares team 'National League Champions' hours before Game 4
text:
Mets Web site declares team ‘National League Champions’ hours before Game 4 Resize Text By Des Bieler October 21 at 8:16 PM Follow @DesBieler Daniel Murphy and his teammates were still warming up for Game 4 when the Mets’ Web site jumped the gun in a big way. (Elsa/Getty Images) 
The Mets very well may become National League champions, possibly as soon as Wednesday night, if they win Game 4 of the NLCS against the Cubs. But as of Wednesday afternoon, all the team had was a 3-0 lead in the series — a commanding position to be sure, but a guarantee of nothing ( as the 2004 Yankees could tell their neighbors ). 
Nevertheless, hours before the first pitch of Game 4, visitors to the Mets’ official Web site were presented with a startling sight: merchandise celebrating New York’s capture of the pennant. @AdamRubinESPN This popped up on the #Mets website. Glitch or confidence? pic.twitter.com/etZfQhQbMD 
— Rob Willis (@willis_ra) October 21, 2015 #Mets ' website jumps the gun, declares team #NLCS champs. Not so fast! GO CUBS!!! https://t.co/GPfiQFzwDQ pic.twitter.com/I4bdO1UQ6G 
— ABC 7 Chicago (@ABC7Chicago) October 21, 2015 
There was some speculation that, on “Back to the Future Day,” someone in the Mets’ organization actually had gotten his or her hands on a sports almanac printed (yeah, right) years from now, indicating that the team really had won the 2015 pennant. But, no, it was just a mistake. 
From a report by the New York Daily News : 
Bob Bowman, the CEO of MLB Advanced Media, told the News Wednesday the mistake was on them, not the Mets. 
“We run all the websites, someone obviously, despite all processes, pushed the wrong button. We deeply apologize.” 
So there you have it, just an honest mistake. OR … was it the work of a Cubs fan secretly trying to place on all-time jinx on the Mets?! No, probably just a mistake. 
A mistake, though, that will loom large in Mets lore if the team somehow blows this thing. Des writes for the Early Lead and the D.C. Sports Bog, scouring the Web to bring readers items of interest, both serious and amusing. He also covers fantasy football, as well as fitness topics for the MisFits. sports Success!
